dt: {bc}to move aimlessly from place to place

dt.t: After one {wi}rambles{/wi} through the maps for a time … some overall impressions begin to emerge.

dt: {bc}to talk or write in an aimless, erratic, and often long-winded fashion

dt.t: The hunk starts to {wi}ramble{/wi} on and on, and the women seem quite annoyed.

dt: {bc}to be related or written in a long-winded or wandering fashion

dt.t: To me, pea greens are the culinary equivalent of morning glories, sprouting overnight, {wi}rambling{/wi} here and there, turning the grower into a shepherd, at least for the duration.

pt: {sc}wander{/sc} {sc}roam{/sc} {sc}ramble{/sc} {sc}rove{/sc} {sc}traipse{/sc} {sc}meander{/sc} mean to go about from place to place usually without a plan or definite purpose. {sc}wander{/sc} implies an absence of or an indifference to a fixed course.

pt.t: fond of {it}wandering{/it} about the square just watching the people

pt: {sc}roam{/sc} suggests wandering about freely and often far afield.
{sc}ramble{/sc} stresses carelessness and indifference to one's course or objective.

pt.t: the speaker {it}rambled{/it} on without ever coming to the point

pt: {sc}rove{/sc} suggests vigorous and sometimes purposeful roaming.
{sc}traipse{/sc} implies a course that is erratic but may sometimes be purposeful.

pt.t: {it}traipsed{/it} all over town looking for the right dress

pt: {sc}meander{/sc} implies a winding or intricate course suggestive of aimless or listless wandering.

pt.t: the river {it}meanders{/it} for miles through rich farmland

et: Middle English, probably alteration of {it}romblen{/it}, frequentative of {it}romen{/it} to roam
shortdef: to move aimlessly from place to place
to talk or write in an aimless, erratic, and often long-winded fashion
